00016 #include <iostream>
00017 #include <stdexcept>
00018 #include <vector>
00019 #include <iterator>
00020 #include <algorithm>            // For std::transform
00021 #include <sstream>              // For VectorToString

00029 
00030 namespace RandomLib {
00031   /**
00032    * \brief A base class for random generators
00033    *
00034    * This provides facilities for managing the seed and for converting the seed
00035    * into random generator state.
00036    *
00037    * The seed is taken to be a vector of unsigned longs of arbitrary length.
00038    * (Only the low 32 bit of each element of the vector are used.)  The class
00039    * provides several methods for setting the seed, static functions for
00040    * producing "random" and "unique" seeds, and facilities for converting the
00041    * seed to a string so that it can be printed easily.
00042    *
00043    * The seeding algorithms are those used by
00044    * <a href="http://www.math.sci.hiroshima-u.ac.jp/~m-mat/MT/emt.html">
00045    * MT19937</a> with some modifications to make all states accessible and to
00046    * minimize the likelihood of different seeds giving the same state.
00047    *
00048    * Finally some low-level routines are provided to facilitate the creation of
00049    * I/O methods for the random generator.
00050    *
00051    * A random generator class can be written based on this class.  The
00052    * generator class would use the base class methods for setting the seed and
00053    * for converting the seed into state.  It would provide the machinery for
00054    * advancing the state and for producing random data.  It is also responsible
00055    * for the routine to save and restore the generator state (including the
00056    * seed).
00057    *
00058    * Written by Charles Karney <charles@karney.com> and licensed under the
00059    * MIT/X11 License.  The seeding algorithms are adapted from those of
00060    * <a href="http://www.math.sci.hiroshima-u.ac.jp/~m-mat/MT/emt.html">
00061    * MT19937</a>.  For more information, see http://randomlib.sourceforge.net/
00062    **********************************************************************/
00063   class RANDOM_EXPORT RandomSeed {
00064   public:
00065     typedef Random_u32 u32;
00066     typedef Random_u64 u64;
00067 
00068     virtual ~RandomSeed() throw() = 0;
00069     /**
00070      * A type large enough to hold the seed words.  This is needs to hold 32
00071      * bits and is an unsigned long for portability.
00072      **********************************************************************/
00073     typedef RandomType<32, unsigned long> seed_t;
00074     typedef seed_t::type seed_type;
00075 
00076     /**
00077      * \name Resetting the seed
00078      **********************************************************************/
00079     ///@{
00080     /**
00081      * Set the seed to a vector \e v.  Only the low \e 32 bits of each element
00082      * are used.
00083      *
00084      * @tparam IntType the integral type of the elements of the vector.
00085      * @param[in] v the vector of elements.
00086      **********************************************************************/
00087     template<typename IntType> void Reseed(const std::vector<IntType>& v) {
00088       Reseed(v.begin(), v.end());
00089     }
00090     /**
00091      * Set the seed to [\e a, \e b) from a pair of iterators.  The iterator
00092      * must produce results which can be converted into seed_type.  Only the
00093      * low 32 bits of each element are used.
00094      *
00095      * @tparam InputIterator the type of the iterator.
00096      * @param[in] a the beginning iterator.
00097      * @param[in] b the ending iterator.
00098      **********************************************************************/
00099     template<typename InputIterator>
00100     void Reseed(InputIterator a, InputIterator b) {
00101       // Read new seed into temporary so as not to change object on error.
00102       std::vector<seed_type> t;
00103       std::transform(a, b, back_inserter(t),
00104                      seed_t::cast<typename std::iterator_traits<InputIterator>
00105                      ::value_type>);
00106       _seed.swap(t);
00107       Reset();
00108     }
00109     /**
00110      * Set the seed to [\e n].  Only the low 32 bits of \e n are used.
00111      *
00112      * @param[in] n the new seed to use.
00113      **********************************************************************/
00114     void Reseed(seed_type n) {
00115       // Reserve space for new seed so as not to change object on error.
00116       _seed.reserve(1);
00117       _seed.resize(1);
00118       _seed[0] = seed_t::cast(n);
00119       Reset();
00120     }
00121     /**
00122      * Set the seed to [SeedVector()].  This is the standard way to reseed with
00123      * a "unique" seed.
00124      **********************************************************************/
00125     void Reseed() { Reseed(SeedVector()); }
00126     /**
00127      * Set the seed from the string \e s using Random::StringToVector.
00128      *
00129      * @param[in] s the string to be decoded into a seed.
00130      **********************************************************************/
00131     void Reseed(const std::string& s) {
00132       // Read new seed into temporary so as not to change object on error.
00133       std::vector<seed_type> t = StringToVector(s);
00134       _seed.swap(t);
00135       Reset();
00136     }
00137     ///@}
00138 
00139     /**
00140      * \name Examining the seed
00141      **********************************************************************/
00142     ///@{
00143     /**
00144      * Return reference to the seed vector (read-only).
00145      *
00146      * @return the seed vector.
00147      **********************************************************************/
00148     const std::vector<seed_type>& Seed() const throw() { return _seed; }
00149     /**
00150      * Format the current seed suitable for printing.
00151      *
00152      * @return the seedd as a string.
00153      **********************************************************************/
00154     std::string SeedString() const { return VectorToString(_seed); }
00155     ///@}
00156 
00157     /**
00158      * \name Resetting the random seed
00159      **********************************************************************/
00160     ///@{
00161     /**
00162      * Resets the sequence to its just-seeded state.  This needs to be declared
00163      * virtual here so that the Reseed functions can call it after saving the
00164      * seed.
00165      **********************************************************************/
00166     virtual void Reset() throw() = 0;
00167     ///@}
00168 
00169     /**
00170      * \name Static functions for seed management
00171      **********************************************************************/
00172     ///@{
00173     /**
00174      * Return a 32 bits of data suitable for seeding the random generator.  The
00175      * result is obtained by combining data from /dev/urandom, gettimeofday,
00176      * time, and getpid to provide a reasonably "random" word of data.
00177      * Usually, it is safer to seed the random generator with SeedVector()
00178      * instead of SeedWord().
00179      *
00180      * @return a single "more-or-less random" seed_type to be used as a seed.
00181      **********************************************************************/
00182     static seed_type SeedWord();
00183     /**
00184      * Return a vector of unsigned longs suitable for seeding the random
00185      * generator.  The vector is almost certainly unique; however, the results
00186      * of successive calls to Random::SeedVector() will be correlated.  If
00187      * several Random objects are required within a single program execution,
00188      * call Random::SeedVector once, print it out (!), push_back additional
00189      * data to identify the instance (e.g., loop index, thread ID, etc.), and
00190      * use the result to seed the Random object.  The number of elements
00191      * included in the vector may depend on the operating system.  Additional
00192      * elements may be added in future versions of this library.
00193      *
00194      * @return a "unique" vector of seed_type to be uses as a seed.
00195      **********************************************************************/
00196     static std::vector<seed_type> SeedVector();
00197     /**
00198      * Convert a vector into a string suitable for printing or as an argument
00199      * for Random::Reseed(const std::string& s).
00200      *
00201      * @tparam IntType the integral type of the elements of the vector.
00202      * @param[in] v the vector to be converted.
00203      * @return the resulting string.
00204      **********************************************************************/
00205     template<typename IntType>
00206     static std::string VectorToString(const std::vector<IntType>& v) {
00207       std::ostringstream os;
00208       os << "[";
00209       for (typename std::vector<IntType>::const_iterator n = v.begin();
00210            n != v.end(); ++n) {
00211         if (n != v.begin())
00212           os << ",";
00213         // Normalize in case this is called by user.
00214         os << seed_t::cast(*n);
00215       }
00216       os << "]";
00217       return os.str();
00218     }
00219     /**
00220      * Convert a string into a vector of seed_type suitable for printing or as
00221      * an argument for Random::Reseed(const std::vector<seed_type>& v).  Reads
00222      * consecutive digits in string.  Thus "[1,2,3]" => [1,2,3]; "-0.123e-4" =>
00223      * [0,123,4], etc.  strtoul understands C's notation for octal and
00224      * hexadecimal, for example "012 10 0xa" => [10,10,10].  Reading of a
00225      * number stops at the first illegal character for the base.  Thus
00226      * "2006-04-08" => [2006,4,0,8] (i.e., 08 becomes two numbers).  Note that
00227      * input numbers greater than ULONG_MAX overflow to ULONG_MAX, which
00228      * probably will result in the number being interpreted as LONG_MASK.
00229      *
00230      * @param[in] s the string to be converted.
00231      * @return the resulting vector of seed_type.
00232      **********************************************************************/
00233     static std::vector<seed_type> StringToVector(const std::string& s);
00234     ///@}
00235 
00236   protected:
00237     /**
00238      * The seed vector
00239      **********************************************************************/
00240     std::vector<seed_type> _seed;
00241 
00242   };
00243 
00244   inline RandomSeed::~RandomSeed() throw() {}
00245 
00246 } // namespace RandomLib
